data.en: Organize your network resources and manage user access through Active Directory.

data: On your "DC-Server", open Active Directory Users and Computers from the Tools menu in Server Manager.
Create an OU (Organizational Unit): Right-click your domain -> New -> Organizational Unit. (Ous -> Jubail , Khobar , Riyadh).
Create a Group: Right-click on the "Ous" -> New -> Group. ("Sales" , "Marketing").
Create a User: Right-click on the "Ous -> Jubail , Khobar , Riyadh" -> New -> User. Fill in the details and set a password.
Add User to Group: Douple-click on the Groups ("Sales" , "Marketing") -> "Member". Enter the username ("Rami , Jamal ...") and click Check nems -> apply.

data.en: Cisco IOS has a hierarchical structure. You move through different modes to perform different tasks. The prompt changes to show your current mode.

data: User EXEC Mode (Switch>): For basic monitoring and viewing commands.
Privileged EXEC Mode (Switch#): Also called "enable mode". Provides access to all monitoring commands as well as device management commands like `reload` and `copy`.
Global Configuration Mode (Switch(config)#): The gateway to all configuration changes.
Specific Configuration Modes (e.g., Switch(config-if)#): For configuring specific parts of the device, like an interface or a routing protocol.

content.data:
! From User EXEC, enter Privileged EXEC mode
Switch>enable
Switch#

! From Privileged EXEC, enter Global Configuration mode
Switch#configure terminal
Enter configuration commands, one per line.  End with CNTL/Z.
Switch(config)#

! Exit back one level
Switch(config)#exit
Switch#

! Return directly to Privileged EXEC mode from any config mode
Switch(config-if)#end
Switch#

data.en: These are some of the first commands you should execute on a new device to give it a unique identity.
Changes the name of the switch or router, which is reflected in the CLI prompt.

content.data:
Switch(config)#hostname SW1
SW1(config)#

data.en: Sets a banner that is displayed to anyone who connects to the device. It's often used for legal warnings.

content.data:
! The '#' is a delimiting character; the banner ends when it sees the second '#'
SW1(config)#banner motd # UNAUTHORIZED ACCESS IS PROHIBITED #

data.en: Interfaces are the physical ports on the device. They must be configured to pass traffic.

content.data:
! Enter interface configuration mode for GigabitEthernet 0/1
SW1(config)#interface gigabitEthernet 0/1

! Add a description to the interface (highly recommended)
SW1(config-if)#description Link to Core Router

! On a router or Layer 3 switch, assign an IP address
SW1(config-if)#ip address 192.168.1.1 255.255.255.0

! Enable the interface (ports are disabled by default)
SW1(config-if)#no shutdown
SW1(config-if)#
%LINK-5-CHANGED: Interface GigabitEthernet0/1, changed state to up
%LINEPROTO-5-UPDOWN: Line protocol on Interface GigabitEthernet0/1, changed state to up

! To disable an interface
SW1(config-if)#shutdown

data.en: `show` commands are used in User EXEC or Privileged EXEC mode to view the device's status and configuration. They are essential for verification and troubleshooting.

content.data:
! Display the current, active configuration
SW1#show running-config

! Display the configuration that will be loaded on reboot
SW1#show startup-config

! A summary of all interfaces, their IP addresses, and status (very useful!)
SW1#show ip interface brief
Interface              IP-Address      OK? Method Status                Protocol
GigabitEthernet0/1     192.168.1.1     YES manual up                    up
GigabitEthernet0/2     unassigned      YES manual administratively down down

! Display detailed information about the IOS version and hardware
SW1#show version
Cisco IOS Software, C2960 Software (C2960-LANBASEK9-M), Version 15.0(2)SE4...
...

data.en: Changes made in global configuration mode are applied immediately to the `running-config`. To make them permanent, you must save them to the `startup-config`.

content.data:
! Copies the active configuration from RAM to NVRAM
SW1#copy running-config startup-config
Destination filename [startup-config]?
Building configuration...
[OK]

data.en: To completely wipe a switch and return it to its factory default state, you must erase the startup configuration and the VLAN database, then reload.

content.data:
! Erase the startup configuration file
SW1#erase startup-config
Erasing the nvram filesystem will remove all configuration files! Continue? [confirm]
[OK]
Erase of nvram: complete

! Delete the VLAN database file
SW1#delete flash:vlan.dat
Delete filename [vlan.dat]?
Delete flash:/vlan.dat? [confirm]

! Reboot the switch
SW1#reload
Proceed with reload? [confirm]

data.en: The `?` is your most powerful tool. Use it to see available commands or the options for a command you're typing.

content.data:
! See all commands that start with 'cl'
SW1#cl?
clear  clock

! See the next required parameter for 'clock set'
SW1#clock set ?
  hh:mm:ss  Current Time

! See what comes next
SW1#clock set 14:30:00 ?
    Day of the month
  MONTH   Month of the year

! Keep going until you see  (carriage return)
SW1#clock set 14:30:00 1 October 2025 ?

data.en: The Domain Controller is the heart of a Windows network, managing security and user authentication.
A. Add the AD DS Role

data: On your "DC-Server" VM, open Server Manager.
Click "Add roles and features".
Choose "Role-based or feature-based installation".
Select your server from the server pool.
Check the box for Active Directory Domain Services. Add the required features when prompted.
Complete the wizard by clicking "Next" through the remaining steps and finally "Install".

data.en: B. Promote Server to a Domain Controller

data: After the installation, a notification flag will appear in Server Manager. Click it and select "Promote this server to a domain controller".
Select "Add a new forest".
Enter a Root domain name (e.g., `M014.com`).
Set a DSRM (Directory Services Restore Mode) password. This is a crucial recovery password.
Proceed through the wizard, accepting defaults, and finally click "Install". The server will restart automatically.

data.en: Device Manager is a vital tool for managing hardware components and their drivers. It can be accessed quickly by running the command devmgmt.msc.
To open Device Manager: Press Windows Logo + R, type devmgmt.msc, and press Enter.

data: View Devices: See all hardware installed on the computer, organized by category. A yellow exclamation mark indicates a problem with the device or its driver.
Update Driver: Right-click a device and select "Update driver" to search for a new driver automatically or manually.
Roll Back Driver: If a new driver causes issues, you can revert to the previously installed one. Right-click the device -> Properties -> Driver tab -> Roll Back Driver.
Disable/Enable Device: Temporarily turn a device off or on without uninstalling it.
Uninstall Device: Completely remove a device and its driver from the system.

data.en: Setting up the environment for the server.

data: Open Hyper-V Manager.
Click New > Virtual Machine.

Name: "DHCP_[Last 3 Digits of ID]"
(Example: DHCP_789).
Generation: Select Generation 2 (Recommended).
Memory: Assign at least 4096 MB (4GB).
Networking: Select your "External Switch".
Installation: Select the Windows Server 2022 ISO.
Open Server Manager > Add Roles and Features.
Check DHCP Server and DNS Server.
Click Install.
After install, click the Notification flag and select "Complete DHCP Configuration".

data.en: Defining the pool of IP addresses with specific local network requirements.

data: Open Tools > DHCP.
Right-click IPv4 > New Scope.

IP Address Range:
  • Start IP: 192.168.1.3
End IP: 192.168.1.254
Subnet Mask: 255.255.255.0

Add Exclusions (Execute):
  • Start IP: 192.168.1.10
End IP: 192.168.1.30
(These addresses will NOT be distributed)
Lease Duration: Set "Limited to" days: 100 Days.
Configure DHCP Options: Select "Yes, I want to configure these options now".
Router (Default Gateway): SKIP THIS STEP. Leave it blank (Local Network Only).
DNS Server: Ensure the server's own IP is listed (e.g., 192.168.1.10).
Activate the Scope.

data.en: Joining the server to an existing Active Directory.

data: Open System Properties.
Click Change... settings.
Select Domain and type the name (e.g., mycompany.local).
Enter Domain Admin credentials.
Restart the server.

data.en: Verify on a Windows 10/11 Client Machine.

data: Set Network Adapter to "Obtain an IP address automatically".
Run these commands in CMD:

content.data:
C:\> ipconfig /release
C:\> ipconfig /renew
C:\> ipconfig /all

data.en: How to create partition and format using CMD
These commands are run directly in the Command Prompt, not inside the `diskpart` utility.
Prepares a storage drive for use by creating a new file system. Warning: This erases all data on the specified drive.

content.data:
C:\>format D: /fs:ntfs /q /v:Data
The type of the file system is RAW.
The new file system is NTFS.
QuickFormatting 953869M
Creating file system structures.
Format complete.

data.en: Displays the volume label and serial number for a specific drive.

content.data:
C:\>vol C:
 Volume in drive C is Windows
 Volume Serial Number is 1A2B-3C4D

data.en: Creates, changes, or deletes the volume label (name) of a disk.

content.data:
C:\>label D: Backup
Volume in drive D is Data
Volume Serial Number is ABCD-EF98
Volume label (11 characters, ENTER for none)? Backup

data.en: A powerful utility for advanced disk management. Start it by typing diskpart in an elevated Command Prompt.
Used to view and select disks, partitions, or volumes to work on.

content.data:
DISKPART>list disk
  Disk ###  Status         Size     Free     Dyn  Gpt
  --------  -------------  -------  -------  ---  ---
  Disk 0    Online          931 GB      0 B        *
  Disk 1    Online           58 GB    58 GB
DISKPART>select disk 1
Disk 1 is now the selected disk.
DISKPART>list partition
  Partition ###  Type              Size     Offset
  -------------  ----------------  -------  -------
  Partition 1    Primary             20 GB  1024 KB
  Partition 2    Extended            38 GB    20 GB
  Partition 3    Logical             10 GB    20 GB

data.en: This example shows how to partition a new disk using the modern GPT style.

content.data:
! Select, clean, and convert the disk to GPT
DISKPART> select disk 1
DISKPART> clean
DISKPART> convert gpt
! Create a 100GB primary partition
DISKPART> create partition primary size=100000
DiskPart succeeded in creating the specified partition.
! Format and assign a letter
DISKPART> format fs=ntfs quick label="Windows"
DiskPart successfully formatted the volume.
DISKPART> assign letter=W
DiskPart successfully assigned the drive letter or mount point.

data.en: Commands to change or remove existing partitions.

content.data:
! Extend the selected volume by 5GB (5000MB)
DISKPART>extend size=5000
DiskPart successfully extended the volume.

! Shrink the selected volume by 10GB (10000MB)
DISKPART>shrink desired=10000
DiskPart successfully shrunk the volume by: 10 GB

! Remove the drive letter G from the selected volume
DISKPART>remove letter=G
DiskPart successfully removed the drive letter or mount point.

! Delete the currently selected partition (erases data)
DISKPART>delete partition
DiskPart successfully deleted the selected partition.

data.en: Commands to get details about disks and supported file systems.

content.data:
! Get detailed information about the currently selected disk
DISKPART>detail disk
SAMSUNG MZ77Q1T0B/003 (SSD)
    Disk ID: {1234ABCD-5678-90EF-1234-567890ABCDEF}
    ...

! See all supported file systems for formatting
DISKPART>filesystems

  File System  Type        Size
  -----------  ----------  -----------------------
  NTFS         NTFS        Up to 256 TB
  ...

data.en: This workflow shows the complete process of creating a VHD, converting it to the legacy MBR style, and creating primary, extended, and logical partitions.

content.data:
! Create a 5GB VHD file
DISKPART>create vdisk file="C:\vhd1.vhd" maximum=5000
  100 percent completed
DiskPart successfully created the virtual disk file.

! Select and attach the VHD to the system
DISKPART>select vdisk file="C:\vhd1.vhd"
DiskPart successfully selected the virtual disk file.
DISKPART>attach vdisk
  100 percent completed
DiskPart successfully attached the virtual disk file.

! Convert the attached VHD to MBR style
DISKPART>convert mbr
DiskPart successfully converted the selected disk to MBR format.

! Create a 2GB Primary Partition (Max 4 on MBR)
DISKPART>create partition primary size=2000
DiskPart succeeded in creating the specified partition.

! Create an Extended Partition with the remaining space (Max 1 per disk)
DISKPART>create partition extended
DiskPart succeeded in creating the specified partition.

! Create a 1GB Logical drive inside the extended partition (Unlimited logical drives)
DISKPART>create partition logical size=1000
DiskPart succeeded in creating the specified partition.

! Select the first partition (the primary one) to format it
DISKPART>select partition 1
Partition 1 is now the selected partition.

! Format and assign a letter
DISKPART>format fs=ntfs quick label="VHD_Primary"
  100 percent completed
DiskPart successfully formatted the volume.
DISKPART>assign letter=V
DiskPart successfully assigned the drive letter or mount point.

data.en: Use Diskpart to prepare a USB flash drive to be a bootable Windows installation medium. Warning: This will erase all data on the USB drive.

content.data:
// 1. Identify your USB drive (e.g., Disk 2)
DISKPART> list disk
  Disk ###  Status         Size     Free     Dyn  Gpt
  --------  -------------  -------  -------  ---  ---
  Disk 0    Online          465 GB      0 B        *
  Disk 1    Online          931 GB      0 B        *
  Disk 2    Online           58 GB      0 B

// 2. Select the USB drive
DISKPART> select disk 2
Disk 2 is now the selected disk.

// 3. Wipe the drive
DISKPART> clean
DiskPart succeeded in cleaning the disk.

// 4. Create a primary partition
DISKPART> create partition primary
DiskPart succeeded in creating the specified partition.

// 5. Select and mark the partition as active (bootable)
DISKPART> select partition 1
Partition 1 is now the selected partition.
DISKPART> active
DiskPart marked the current partition as active.

// 6. Format the partition as FAT32
DISKPART> format fs=fat32 quick label="WinSetup"
  100 percent completed
DiskPart successfully formatted the volume.

// 7. Assign a drive letter
DISKPART> assign letter=W
DiskPart successfully assigned the drive letter or mount point.

// 8. Exit diskpart
DISKPART> exit
Leaving DiskPart...

data.en: Warning: After completing these steps, you must copy all files and folders from your Windows installation ISO or DVD directly onto the root of the newly prepared USB drive..
Starts the Disk Cleanup tool to free up space on your hard disk. It searches for and analyzes temporary files that can be safely deleted.

data: /LOWDISK - Launches with default settings (checked by default).
/VERYLOWDISK - Launches without user prompts (aggressive cleanup).

content.data:
C:\WINDOWS\system32>cleanmgr /LOWDISK
[Opens the Disk Cleanup GUI dialog]

data.en: Checks a disk for file system errors and bad sectors and attempts to repair them.

data: /f - Fixes errors on the disk.
/r - Locates bad sectors and recovers readable information.
/scan - Runs an online scan on the volume (NTFS only).

data.en: Example: Check and repair the D: drive.

content.data:
C:\WINDOWS\system32>chkdsk D: /r
The type of the file system is NTFS.
Volume label is Data.

Chkdsk cannot run because the volume is in use by another
process. Would you like to schedule this volume to be
checked the next time the system restarts? (Y/N) Y

This volume will be checked the next time the system restarts.

data.en: Analyzes and defragments files on local volumes to improve system performance.

data: /A - Perform analysis only.
/C - Perform the operation on all volumes (Select All).
/D - Perform traditional defragmentation (default).

data.en: Example: Analyze the C: drive for fragmentation.

content.data:
C:\WINDOWS\system32>defrag C: /a
Microsoft Drive Optimizer
Copyright (c) 2013 Microsoft Corp.

Invoking analysis on (C:)...

The operation completed successfully.

Post Defragmentation Report:
        Volume Information:
                Volume size                = 465.23 GB
                Free space                 = 123.45 GB
                Total fragmented space     = 5%
                Largest free space size    = 50.12 GB

You do not need to defragment this volume.

data.en: RIP is a distance-vector routing protocol that uses hop count as its metric. It's simple to configure but is best suited for smaller networks.

content.data:
! Enter RIP configuration mode
Router(config)# router rip
! Specify RIP version 2 (which is classless)
Router(config-router)# version 2
! Advertise the directly connected networks
Router(config-router)# network 192.168.1.0
Router(config-router)# network 10.0.0.0

data.en: OSPF is a link-state routing protocol that is more scalable and efficient than RIP, making it suitable for larger networks. It uses cost as its metric, which is based on bandwidth.

content.data:
! Enter OSPF configuration mode with a process ID (e.g., 1)
Router(config)# router ospf 1
! Advertise networks using a network address, wildcard mask, and area ID
Router(config-router)# network 192.168.1.0 0.0.0.255 area 0
Router(config-router)# network 10.10.10.0 0.0.0.255 area 0

data.en: The wildcard mask is the inverse of a subnet mask (e.g., for 255.255.255.0, the wildcard is 0.0.0.255). All routers in an OSPF setup must have at least one interface in area 0, the backbone area.

content.data:
! Show the IP routing table to see routes learned via RIP (R) or OSPF (O)
Router# show ip route
...
O     192.168.2.0/24 [110/2] via 10.10.10.2, 00:05:32, Serial0/0/0
R     172.16.0.0/16 [120/1] via 10.10.10.2, 00:00:15, Serial0/0/0
...

! Show information about OSPF neighbors
Router# show ip ospf neighbor

Neighbor ID     Pri   State           Dead Time   Address         Interface
192.168.2.1       1   FULL/BDR        00:00:38    10.10.10.2      Serial0/0/0

data.en: Before configuring servers, you need to set up the virtual environment. This involves creating the virtual machines and configuring their network settings.

data: Open Hyper-V Manager.
Create three new Virtual Machines (e.g., "DC-Server", "File-Server", "Client-PC").
Create new Virtual Switch (Private and connect all VMs with it).
On the main page of Hyper-V click on Virtual Switch Manager
Choose Private then click Create Virtual Switch
Install Windows Server on "DC-Server" and "File-Server", and Windows 10/11 on "Client-PC".

data.en: Static IPs are crucial for servers. Ensure all machines are on the same subnet.

data:
DC-Server:
  • IP Address: 192.168.1.1
Subnet Mask: 255.255.255.0
Default Gateway: (Your network's gateway, e.g., 192.168.1.1)
Preferred DNS: 192.168.1.1 (It will be its own DNS server)

File-Server:
  • IP Address: 192.168.1.10
Subnet Mask: 255.255.255.0
Default Gateway: (Your network's gateway, e.g., 192.168.1.1)
Preferred DNS: 192.168.1.1 (Points to the DC for name resolution)

Client-PC:
  • IP Address: 192.168.1.2
Subnet Mask: 255.255.255.0
Default Gateway: (Your network's gateway, e.g., 192.168.1.1)
Preferred DNS: 192.168.1.1 (Points to the DC)

data.en: C. Assign IPs and ping Between DC-server and Client-PC
2. Assign ip to client Pc and ping
NOTE: if u didn't get Reply , check IP ,DNS , and Network file sharing settings

content.data:
C:\>Ping 192.168.1.1
Reply from 192.168.1.1: bytes=32 time<1ms TTL=128
Reply from 192.168.1.1: bytes=32 time<1ms TTL=128
Reply from 192.168.1.1: bytes=32 time=1ms TTL=128
Reply from 192.168.1.1: bytes=32 time<1ms TTL=128

Ping statistics for 192.168.1.1:
    Packets: Sent = 4, Received = 4, Lost = 0 (0% loss),
Approximate round trip times in milli-seconds:
    Minimum = 0ms, Maximum = 1ms, Average = 0ms

data.en: EtherChannel bundles multiple physical switch ports into a single logical link, providing higher bandwidth and redundancy. Configuration can be done using a dynamic protocol (LACP or PAgP) or manually.
LACP (Link Aggregation Control Protocol) - IEEE Standard
Uses active mode to initiate negotiation and passive mode to wait for the other side.

content.data:
! On Switch1 (initiator)
SW1(config)# interface range GigabitEthernet0/1 - 2
SW1(config-if-range)# channel-group 1 mode active

! On Switch2 (listener)
SW2(config)# interface range GigabitEthernet0/1 - 2
SW2(config-if-range)# channel-group 1 mode passive

data.en: Uses desirable mode to initiate negotiation and auto mode to wait for the other side.

content.data:
! On Switch1 (initiator)
SW1(config)# interface range GigabitEthernet0/1 - 2
SW1(config-if-range)# channel-group 1 mode desirable

! On Switch2 (listener)
SW2(config)# interface range GigabitEthernet0/1 - 2
SW2(config-if-range)# channel-group 1 mode auto

data.en: A Layer 3 EtherChannel acts as a routed interface, not a switched one. This is useful for creating high-bandwidth routed links between multilayer switches.

data: Convert the physical ports to Layer 3 interfaces using the no switchport command.
Bundle them into a channel-group.
Assign an IP address to the logical Port-channel interface.

content.data:
Switch1(config)# interface range FastEthernet0/1 - 2
Switch1(config-if-range)# no switchport
Switch1(config-if-range)# channel-group 12 mode on
Switch1(config-if-range)# exit

Switch1(config)# interface Port-channel 12
Switch1(config-if)# ip address 192.168.12.1 255.255.255.0
Switch1(config-if)# no shutdown

! Provides a concise summary of all EtherChannel links
Switch# show etherchannel summary

    Flags:  D - down        P - bundled in port-channel
        I - stand-alone s - suspended
        H - Hot-standby (LACP only)
        R - Layer3      S - Layer2
        U - in use      f - failed to allocate aggregator

Group  Port-channel  Protocol    Ports
------+-------------+-----------+-----------------------------------------------
1      Po1(SU)         LACP        Gi0/1(P)    Gi0/2(P)

data.en: After you create a an etherchannel you enable Load balancing on both switches by doing the following:

content.data:
Switch1(config)# port-channel load-balance ?

 dst-ip       Dst IP Addr
 dst-mac      Dst Mac Addr
 src-dst-ip   Src XOR Dst IP Addr
 src-dst-mac  Src XOR Dst Mac Addr
 src-ip       Src IP Addr
 src-mac      Src Mac Addr
 
Switch(config)#port-channel load-balance dst-mac

data.en: A file server provides centralized storage and access to files on the network.
A. Add the File Server Role

data: On your "File-Server" VM, open Server Manager.
Go to "Add roles and features".
Under Server Roles, expand "File and Storage Services" -> "File and iSCSI Services", and check File Server.
Complete the wizard to install the role.
In Server Manager, go to "File and Storage Services" -> "Shares".
In the "SHARES" tile, click "TASKS" -> "New Share...".
Choose "SMB Share - Quick" and follow the wizard to specify a share location (e.g., C:\SharedDocs) and name.
Configure permissions as needed (e.g., give "Domain Users" read/write access).

content.data: C:\Users\Jargon\Desktop>mkdir MIT_Project

data.en: Creates a new text file and writes content to it using the output redirection symbol (>).

content.data:
C:\Users\Jargon\Desktop\MIT_Project>echo This is a test file. > readme.txt

C:\Users\Jargon\Desktop\MIT_Project>type readme.txt
This is a test file.

data.en: Displays or changes file and folder attributes. You can manage Read-only (R), Archive (A), System (S), and Hidden (H) attributes.
Managing Attributes for a Single File

data: View attributes: attrib [filename]
Set an attribute: attrib +[attribute] [filename] (e.g., +h for hidden)
Remove an attribute: attrib -[attribute] [filename] (e.g., -r for read-only)

data.en: Example: Make a file read-only and hidden.

content.data:
C:\MIT_Project>attrib +r +h readme.txt

C:\MIT_Project>attrib readme.txt
A    R H      C:\MIT_Project\readme.txt

data.en: Applying Attributes to a Folder and its Contents
You can use switches to apply attributes recursively to all files and subfolders.

data: /s : Processes matching files in the current folder and all subfolders.
/d : Processes folders as well.

data.en: Example: Make the entire MIT_Project folder, and everything inside it, a hidden system folder.

content.data:
C:\Users\Jargon\Desktop>attrib +s +h MIT_Project/*.* /s /d

C:\Users\Jargon\Desktop>attrib MIT_Project
A    S H      C:\Users\Jargon\Desktop\MIT_Project

data.en: Important Note: If a file or folder has the System (S) or Hidden (H) attribute set, you may not be able to change other attributes until you remove them first.

title: Hardware Fault Troubleshooting | PC Troubleshooting Hub

data.en: When a computer fails to boot, the BIOS Power-On Self-Test (POST) may emit beep codes to identify the faulty component.
Correction Note: While some older systems might signal DRAM with "Long + Short", the standard for modern BIOS is that 1 Long + 2 Short indicates a Graphics (GPU) error, not RAM.
Errors occurring after the BIOS screen usually relate to storage devices.
Symptom: "Select Boot Device" or "Boot Device Not Found".

data: Cause: The HDD is detected but has no OS, or the cable is loose.
Fix: Check SATA data/power cables. Ensure the correct drive is first in the BIOS Boot Order.
Status: Non-Fatal (System has power, just can't load Windows).

data.en: Symptom: CD-ROM or secondary HDD not showing up.

data: Context: Older IDE (PATA) ribbons support two devices: a Master and a Slave.
Fix: Check the Jumpers on the back of the drive. If two devices share a cable, one must be Master and the other Slave.

data.en: If the PC is completely dead (No fans, no lights), the PSU is the prime suspect.
To test a PSU without a motherboard:

data: Unplug the PSU from the wall.
Locate the large 24-pin motherboard connector.
Find the Green Wire (PS_ON) and any Black Wire (Ground).
Bridge them with a paperclip or wire.
Plug the PSU back into the wall.

data.en: Result: If the PSU fan spins, it is likely turning on. If not, the PSU is dead.
If the system powers on but is unstable (e.g., random restarts), check the voltages:

data: Yellow Wire: +12V (CPU/GPU Power).
Red Wire: +5V (Disk drives/logic).
Orange Wire: +3.3V (M.2 drives/RAM).

data.en: Issues with modems, network cards, or sound cards.

data: Symptom: Device not detected in Device Manager.
Status: Non-Fatal. The PC will still boot.
Fix: Move the card to a different PCI slot to rule out a bad motherboard slot.

data.en: This method uses a router with a single physical interface connected to a switch via a trunk link to route between multiple VLANs. The router's physical interface is divided into logical "subinterfaces", one for each VLAN.

content.data:
! On the Switch, configure the port connected to the router as a trunk
Switch(config)# interface GigabitEthernet0/1
Switch(config-if)# switchport mode trunk
Switch(config-if)# exit

! On the Router, enable the physical interface
Router(config)# interface GigabitEthernet0/1
Router(config-if)# no shutdown
Router(config-if)# exit

! Create a subinterface for VLAN 10
Router(config)# interface GigabitEthernet0/1.10
! Set the encapsulation type to dot1q and specify the VLAN ID
Router(config-subif)# encapsulation dot1q 10
! Assign an IP address to be the default gateway for that VLAN
Router(config-subif)# ip address 192.168.10.1 255.255.255.0
Router(config-subif)# exit

! Create a subinterface for VLAN 20
Router(config)# interface GigabitEthernet0/1.20
Router(config-subif)# encapsulation dot1q 20
Router(config-subif)# ip address 192.168.20.1 255.255.255.0

data.en: A Layer 3 (or multilayer) switch can perform routing functions, eliminating the need for an external router. This is done by creating Switched Virtual Interfaces (SVIs) for each VLAN and enabling IP routing.

content.data:
! Enable IP routing on the Layer 3 switch
L3_Switch(config)# ip routing

! Create an SVI for VLAN 10 and assign its default gateway IP
L3_Switch(config)# Vlan 10
L3_Switch(config)# interface Vlan 10
L3_Switch(config-if)# ip address 10.0.0.1 255.0.0.0
L3_Switch(config-if)# no shutdown
L3_Switch(config-if)# exit

! Create an SVI for VLAN 20 and assign its default gateway IP
L3_Switch(config)# Vlan 20
L3_Switch(config)# interface Vlan 20
L3_Switch(config-if)# ip address 11.0.0.1 255.0.0.0
L3_Switch(config-if)# no shutdown

data.en: NOTE: To be able to join make sure to change "Network and sharing center settings" by turning on all options
and make sure IPs, and DNS are correct
Connect your client machine to the domain to enable centralized login and management.

data: On your "Client-PC" VM, right-click the Start Menu and go to System.
Click on "Rename this PC (advanced)" or "Advanced system settings".
Go to the "Computer Name" tab and click "Change...".
Under "Member of", select Domain and type your domain name (e.g., `M014.com`).
Click OK. You will be prompted for credentials. Enter the username and password of a domain administrator account.
You should see a welcome message. Restart the PC to apply the changes. You can now log in with the domain user account you created.

data.en: Basic commands to navigate directories and manage files.

content.data:
[root@comp1 ~]# pwd
/root # Displays current working directory

[root@comp1 ~]# ls -l   # Long listing (permissions, owner, size)
[root@comp1 ~]# ls -a   # Show hidden files (starts with .)
[root@comp1 ~]# ls -R   # Recursive listing (tree structure)

[root@comp1 ~]# cd /home  # Change directory to /home
[root@comp1 ~]# cd ..     # Go up one level
[root@comp1 ~]# cd ~      # Go to logged-in user's home directory

# Create empty files or update timestamp
[root@comp1 ~]# touch file1.txt file2.txt

# View file contents
[root@comp1 ~]# cat file1.txt
[root@comp1 ~]# cat -n file1.txt # View with line numbers
[root@comp1 ~]# head file1.txt   # First 10 lines
[root@comp1 ~]# tail file1.txt   # Last 10 lines

# Create Directories
[root@comp1 ~]# mkdir mydir
[root@comp1 ~]# mkdir -p dir1/dir2/dir3 # Create nested directories

[root@comp1 ~]# cp source.txt dest.txt      # Copy file
[root@comp1 ~]# cp -r folder1 folder2       # Copy directory recursively

[root@comp1 ~]# mv file1.txt newname.txt    # Rename file
[root@comp1 ~]# mv file1.txt /tmp/          # Move file

[root@comp1 ~]# rm file1.txt                # Remove file
[root@comp1 ~]# rm -rf mydir                # Remove directory forcefully

data.en: The Visual Editor has two main modes: Command Mode (default) and Input Mode.

data: <kbd>i</kbd> : Insert mode (before cursor)
<kbd>a</kbd> : Append mode (after cursor)
<kbd>o</kbd> : Open new line below
<kbd>Esc</kbd> : Return to Command Mode
<kbd>h</kbd> Left | <kbd>j</kbd> Down | <kbd>k</kbd> Up | <kbd>l</kbd> Right
<kbd>w</kbd> : Next word | <kbd>b</kbd> : Previous word
<kbd>$</kbd> : End of line | <kbd>0</kbd> : Start of line
<kbd>G</kbd> : End of file | <kbd>1G</kbd> : Start of file
<kbd>x</kbd> : Delete character
<kbd>dd</kbd> : Delete current line (Cut)
<kbd>yy</kbd> : Copy current line (Yank)
<kbd>p</kbd> : Paste below cursor
<kbd>u</kbd> : Undo last change

content.data:
:w   # Save
:wq  # Save and Quit (or ZZ)
:q!  # Quit without saving (Discard changes)

data.en: Managing file access levels for User (u), Group (g), and Others (o).

content.data:
# Symbolic Method
[root@comp1 ~]# chmod u+x script.sh  # Add execute permission for User
[root@comp1 ~]# chmod g-w file.txt   # Remove write permission for Group
[root@comp1 ~]# chmod a=r file.txt   # Set read-only for All

# Numeric Method (r=4, w=2, x=1)
[root@comp1 ~]# chmod 755 script.sh
# 7 (rwx) for User
# 5 (r-x) for Group
# 5 (r-x) for Others

[root@comp1 ~]# chown ahmed file.txt        # Change user owner
[root@comp1 ~]# chgrp students file.txt     # Change group owner
[root@comp1 ~]# chown -R ahmed /var/www     # Recursive change

# Shutdown
[root@comp1 ~]# shutdown -P now   # Power off immediately
[root@comp1 ~]# shutdown -r now   # Reboot immediately
[root@comp1 ~]# shutdown -c       # Cancel scheduled shutdown

# Other aliases
[root@comp1 ~]# reboot
[root@comp1 ~]# poweroff
[root@comp1 ~]# halt              # Halts system (does not power off)

data.en: Port Address Translation (PAT) is the most common form of NAT. It translates multiple private IP addresses into a single public IP address by using different port numbers to track connections.

data: Define the inside interface (your local network).
Define the outside interface (facing the internet/public network).
Create an Access Control List (ACL) to identify the private IP addresses that are allowed to be translated.
Enable NAT, linking the ACL to the outside interface and enabling overload.

content.data:
! Define the inside interface
Router(config)# interface GigabitEthernet0/0
Router(config-if)# ip nat inside
Router(config-if)# exit

! Define the outside interface
Router(config)# interface GigabitEthernet0/1
Router(config-if)# ip nat outside
Router(config-if)# exit

! Create an access list to permit your private network range
Router(config)# access-list 1 permit 10.0.0.0 0.255.255.255

! Enable NAT, linking the access list to the outside interface with overload
Router(config)# ip nat inside source list 1 interface GigabitEthernet0/1 overload

! Show active NAT translations
Router# show ip nat translations

Pro  Inside global     Inside local      Outside local     Outside global
icmp 209.165.200.226:1 10.0.0.1:1        8.8.8.8:1         8.8.8.8:1
icmp 209.165.200.226:2 10.0.0.2:2        8.8.8.8:2         8.8.8.8:2

data.en: DHCP Server on a Cisco Router
A Cisco router can be configured to act as a DHCP server, automatically assigning IP addresses to clients on the network.

content.data:
! Exclude specific IP addresses from being assigned (e.g., for servers, router itself)
Router(config)# ip dhcp excluded-address 192.168.1.1 192.168.1.10

! Create a DHCP pool with a specific name
Router(config)# ip dhcp pool LAN-POOL-1
! Define the network and subnet mask for the pool
Router(dhcp-config)# network 192.168.1.0 255.255.255.0
! Specify the default gateway for clients
Router(dhcp-config)# default-router 192.168.1.1
! Specify the DNS server for clients
Router(dhcp-config)# dns-server 8.8.8.8

data.en: Clients need to be configured with the IP address of a DNS server to resolve domain names (like www.google.com) into IP addresses. This is typically assigned via DHCP, but can be set manually.
Verification on a Cisco Router (acting as client)

content.data:
! Set the DNS server for the router itself
Router(config)# ip name-server 8.8.8.8

! Test DNS resolution
Router# ping www.cisco.com
Translating "www.cisco.com"...domain server (8.8.8.8) [OK]
Type escape sequence to abort.
Sending 5, 100-byte ICMP Echos to 72.163.4.185, timeout is 2 seconds:
!!!!!
Success rate is 100 percent (5/5), round-trip min/avg/max = 16/18/20 ms

#   
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
for fruit in fruits:
    print(fruit)

#     
for i in range(5): # from 0 to 4
    print(i)

count = 0
while count #    count = count + 1

numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
#    
numbers.append(6)
print(f"After append: {numbers}")

#       (  0)
print(f"First element: {numbers[0]}")

#     
numbers.pop(2) #     2 (  3)
print(f"After pop: {numbers}")

person = {"name": "Fatima", "age": 22, "city": "Dammam"}

#      
print(f"Name: {person['name']}")

#   
person["major"] = "IT"
print(f"After adding major: {person}")

#  
del person["age"]
print(f"After deleting age: {person}")

coordinates = (10.0, 20.0)
print(f"X: {coordinates[0]}, Y: {coordinates[1]}")

#        Tuples   
# coordinates[0] = 15  # TypeError

numbers = {1, 2, 3, 4, 4, 4}
print(f"Set of numbers: {numbers}")

numbers.add(5)
print(f"After adding 5: {numbers}")

numbers.remove(2)
print(f"After removing 2: {numbers}")

# 'w'  (            )
with open("greeting.txt", "w") as file:
    file.write("Hello from Python!\n")
    file.write("This is a new line.")

# 'r' 
with open("greeting.txt", "r") as file:
    content = file.read()
    print(content)

# 'a'        
with open("greeting.txt", "a") as file:
    file.write("\nAppending another line.")

#      
def greet(name):
    print(f"Hello, {name}!")

#     
def add_numbers(x, y):
    return x + y

#   
greet("Ahmed")

#       
sum_result = add_numbers(5, 3)
print(f"The sum is: {sum_result}")

# String ()
name = "Basil"
# Integer ( )
age = 25
# Float ( )
height = 175.5
# Boolean ( )
is_student = True

print(f"Name: {name}, Type: {type(name)}")
print(f"Age: {age}, Type: {type(age)}")

message = "  Hello, World!  "

#     
print(message.upper())

#      
print(message.strip())

#    
print(message.replace("World", "Python"))

#    
print(message.strip().split(','))

name = "Ali"
age = 30
print(f"My name is {name} and I am {age} years old.")

data.en: Combine multiple physical disks into a single logical volume for performance or redundancy. This requires adding extra virtual hard disks to your server VM in Hyper-V settings.

data: Open Disk Management on your server.
Initialize the new disks.
Right-click on an unallocated disk space and choose the desired volume type:
Spanned Volume: Combines space from multiple disks into one large volume. No redundancy.
Striped Volume (RAID 0): Writes data across multiple disks for faster performance. No redundancy.
Mirrored Volume (RAID 1): Duplicates data onto two separate disks for excellent redundancy.
Follow the wizard to select disks and complete the creation.

data.en: The Windows Registry is a hierarchical database that stores low-level settings for the operating system and for applications. Editing it can be dangerous, so it's crucial to back up before making changes.
To open Registry Editor: Press Windows Logo + R, type regedit.exe, and press Enter. (Requires administrator privileges).

data: Navigation: The left pane contains keys (folders). Navigate through them to find the setting you need to modify.
Editing Values: The right pane contains values (settings). Double-click a value to edit it.
Export (Backup): Before editing, right-click the key you plan to change and select "Export". This saves a .reg file that can be used to restore the original settings by double-clicking it.

data.en: Event Viewer is a logbook for your computer. It records significant events, such as application crashes, security audits, driver failures, and system startups. It's one of the first places to look when troubleshooting a problem.
To open Event Viewer: Press Windows Logo + R, type eventvwr.msc, and press Enter.
Under "Windows Logs" in the left pane, you'll find the most important logs:

data: Application: Events logged by applications or programs.
Security: Events related to security, such as login attempts (successful and failed).
Setup: Events related primarily to application setup.
System: Events logged by Windows system components, such as a driver failing to start. This is a critical log for troubleshooting hardware and OS issues.

data.en: Events are classified by level: Information, Warning, Error, and Critical. When troubleshooting, focus on the Error and Critical events first.
Telnet provides basic, unencrypted remote access. It should only be used in secure, isolated lab environments. The configuration involves setting a password on the VTY (Virtual Teletype) lines.

content.data:
! Configure the virtual terminal lines for remote access
Switch(config)# line vty 0 15
! Set a password for Telnet access
Switch(config-line)# password cisco
! Enforce login with the password
Switch(config-line)# login

data.en: SSH provides secure, encrypted remote access and is the industry standard. Configuration is more involved as it requires creating a local user, defining a domain name, and generating encryption keys.

data: Set a hostname and IP domain name.
Generate crypto keys.
Create a local username and password for authentication.
Configure VTY lines to use SSH and authenticate against the local user database.

content.data:
Router(config)# hostname MyRouter
MyRouter(config)# ip domain-name mylab.local
MyRouter(config)# crypto key generate rsa
The name for the keys will be: MyRouter.mylab.local
Choose the size of the key modulus in the range of 360 to 2048 for your
  General Purpose Keys. Choosing a key modulus greater than 512 may take
  a few minutes.

How many bits in the modulus [512]: 1024
% Generating 1024 bit RSA keys, keys will be non-exportable...[OK]

MyRouter(config)# username admin secret cisco123
MyRouter(config)# line vty 0 4
MyRouter(config-line)# transport input ssh
MyRouter(config-line)# login local

data.en: Task Manager provides a real-time view of your system's performance and the applications and processes running on it. It's essential for troubleshooting performance issues and unresponsive applications.
To open Task Manager: Press Ctrl + Shift + Esc, or run taskmgr.exe.

data: Processes: View running applications and background processes. You can right-click an item and select "End task" to force it to close.
Performance: Monitor CPU, Memory, Disk, and Network usage with real-time graphs.
Details: A more advanced view of all running processes with their Process ID (PID), memory usage, and CPU time.

data.en: Windows Services are programs that run in the background, often starting when the computer boots. They perform core OS functions. Misconfigured or failed services can cause system-wide problems.
To open Services: Press Windows Logo + R, type services.msc, and press Enter.
Find the service in the list and double-click it to open its properties. From here you can:

data: Start, Stop, Pause, or Restart the service.

Change its Startup type:
  • Automatic: Starts when Windows boots.
Automatic (Delayed Start): Starts shortly after boot to improve startup time.
Manual: Starts only when needed by an application or another service.
Disabled: Prevents the service from starting at all.

data.en: Some services rely on other services to function. If a service fails to start, checking its dependencies is crucial.

data: Right-click on the specific service (e.g., Print Spooler).
Select Properties from the context menu.
Click on the Dependencies tab at the top of the window.

Review the boxes to see:
                        <ul>
                            <li>"This service depends on the following system components" (Parents).
"The following system components depend on this service" (Children).

data.en: A static route is a manually configured entry in a router's routing table. It tells the router how to reach a specific network that is not directly connected.

content.data:
! On Router1, to reach the 20.0.0.0/8 network, the next hop is 192.168.1.2
Router1(config)# ip route 20.0.0.0 255.0.0.0 192.168.1.2

! On Router2, to reach the 10.0.0.0/8 network, the next hop is 192.168.1.1
Router2(config)# ip route 10.0.0.0 255.0.0.0 192.168.1.1

data.en: A default route, also known as the "gateway of last resort", tells the router where to send traffic when it doesn't have a specific route for the destination network. This is essential for connecting to the internet.
A default route uses 0.0.0.0 0.0.0.0 to match all possible networks.

content.data:
! On a router connected to an ISP, configure a default route to send all unknown traffic to the ISP's router
HQ_Router(config)# ip route 0.0.0.0 0.0.0.0 203.0.113.1
! 203.0.113.1 is the IP address of the next-hop ISP router

Router# show ip route
...
Gateway of last resort is 203.0.113.1 to network 0.0.0.0

S* 0.0.0.0/0 [1/0] via 203.0.113.1
C     192.168.1.0/24 is directly connected, GigabitEthernet0/1
...

data.en: Securing access to the switch's command-line interface (CLI) is the first and most critical step in network security. This involves setting passwords for different access levels to prevent unauthorized configuration changes.
The console port provides direct physical access to the switch. Securing it prevents anyone with a console cable from gaining control.
This method sets a single password for console access.

content.data:
! Enter global configuration mode
Switch>enable
Switch#configure terminal
! Enter console line configuration mode
Switch(config)#line console 0
! Set the password and require it for login
Switch(config-line)#password cisco
Switch(config-line)#login

data.en: Using a Local Username and Password
This is a more secure method as it requires both a username and a password, allowing for better user tracking.

content.data:
! First, create a local user in the database
Switch(config)#username admin password cisco123
! Then, configure the console to use this local database
Switch(config)#line console 0
Switch(config-line)#login local

data.en: Securing the enable mode is crucial as it grants access to all configuration commands.
The enable password is stored in plain text in the configuration by default, making it less secure.

content.data: Switch(config)#enable password class

data.en: The enable secret command is the **preferred method**. It uses a strong MD5 hash to encrypt the password, making it much more secure. It always overrides the `enable password` if both are configured.

content.data: Switch(config)#enable secret class

data.en: By default, passwords like the console and Telnet passwords are stored in plain text. The service password-encryption command encrypts these passwords in the configuration file, adding a basic layer of security.
Note: This uses a weak encryption algorithm and is not a substitute for using `enable secret`, but it's good practice to enable it.

content.data:
! Enable encryption for all plain-text passwords
Switch(config)#service password-encryption

! Viewing the running config will now show encrypted passwords
Switch#show running-config
...
enable password 7 0822455D0A16
...
line console 0
 password 7 0822455D0A16
...

data.en: Port security is a feature that restricts input to an interface by limiting and identifying MAC addresses of the stations allowed to access the port. This prevents unauthorized users from connecting to the network.

data: Set the port to access mode.
Enable port security on the interface.
(Optional) Set the maximum number of allowed MAC addresses. Default is 1.
Define the violation action (shutdown, restrict, or protect). shutdown is the most secure and default action.
Set the method for learning MAC addresses. sticky learns dynamically and saves the address to the running configuration.

content.data:
Switch(config)# interface FastEthernet0/1
Switch(config-if)# switchport mode access
Switch(config-if)# switchport port-security
Switch(config-if)# switchport port-security maximum 1
Switch(config-if)# switchport port-security violation shutdown
Switch(config-if)# switchport port-security mac-address sticky

data.en: You can verify the port security configuration and see which MAC addresses have been learned.

content.data:
! Show the overall port security status for all interfaces
Switch# show port-security
Secure Port  MaxSecureAddr  CurrentAddr  SecurityViolation  Security Action
                (Count)       (Count)          (Count)
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
      Fa0/1              1            1                  0         Shutdown
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Total Addresses in System (configured and dynamic): 1

! Show detailed port security status for a specific interface
Switch# show port-security interface fastEthernet 0/1
Port Security              : Enabled
Port Status                : Secure-up
Violation Mode             : Shutdown
Maximum MAC Addresses      : 1
Total MAC Addresses        : 1
Configured MAC Addresses   : 0
Sticky MAC Addresses       : 1
Last Source Address:Vlan   : 0001.4284.D8E9:1
Security Violation Count   : 0

data.en: When a violation occurs (e.g., an unauthorized device connects), the port will enter an err-disabled state. To re-enable it, you must go to the interface configuration and issue the shutdown command followed by the no shutdown command.
Protect a Cisco switch from another unauthorized switch
Enable BPDU Guard (Prevents Rogue Switches on Access Ports)
The System Properties dialog is a central hub for many advanced settings. It can be accessed quickly by running the command sysdm.cpl.
To open System Properties: Press Windows Logo + R, type sysdm.cpl, and press Enter.
Virtual memory (the paging file) is a space on your hard disk that Windows uses as if it were RAM. You can manage its size and location for performance tuning.

data: Open System Properties (sysdm.cpl).
Go to the Advanced tab.
Under the "Performance" section, click Settings....
In the Performance Options window, go to the Advanced tab.
Under the "Virtual memory" section, click Change....
From here you can uncheck "Automatically manage..." to set a custom size or move the pagefile.sys to a different drive.

data.en: System Restore allows you to revert your computer's system files and settings to an earlier point in time, which can be used to recover from system malfunctions. This feature relies on "restore points".

data: Open System Properties (sysdm.cpl).
Go to the System Protection tab.
Configure: Select a drive (usually C:) and click "Configure..." to turn on system protection and allocate disk space for restore points.
Create: Click "Create..." to manually create a restore point before making major changes like installing a new driver or software.
Restore: Click "System Restore..." to launch the wizard that lets you choose a restore point to revert to. This can also be launched via the command rstrui.exe.

data.en: Provides a detailed summary of the computer's hardware and software configuration.
Example: Display system information in the console.

content.data:
C:\Users\Student>systeminfo

Host Name:                 DESKTOP-JIC01
OS Name:                   Microsoft Windows 10 Enterprise
OS Version:                10.0.19041 N/A Build 19041
OS Manufacturer:           Microsoft Corporation
System Manufacturer:       HP
System Model:              EliteBook 840 G5
System Type:               x64-based PC
Processor(s):              1 Processor(s) Installed.
                           [01]: Intel64 Family 6 Model 142 Stepping 10 GenuineIntel ~2100 Mhz
BIOS Version:              HP Q78 Ver. 01.09.01, 1/25/2022
Total Physical Memory:     8,079 MB
Available Physical Memory: 3,456 MB
...

data.en: Opens the System Information graphical utility, which provides comprehensive technical details about the system.

content.data:
C:\Users\Student>msinfo32
[A graphical window opens showing detailed system information]

data.en: Launches the DirectX Diagnostic Tool, used to troubleshoot video and sound card problems.

content.data:
C:\Users\Student>dxdiag
[A graphical window opens with tabs for System, Display, Sound, and Input]

data.en: Displays the "About Windows" dialog box, showing the specific Windows version and build number.
Example: Check the exact version of Windows.

content.data:
C:\Users\Student>winver
[A dialog box appears with "Microsoft Windows", Version, and OS Build information]

data.en: Lists files and directories. It can also be used to search for files with specific extensions.
Example: Find all Control Panel applets (.cpl files) in the System32 directory.

content.data:
C:\WINDOWS\system32>dir *.cpl
 Volume in drive C has no label.
 Volume Serial Number is 1A2B-3C4D

 Directory of C:\WINDOWS\system32

07/12/2023  09:08 PM           555,008 appwiz.cpl
07/12/2023  09:08 PM           193,024 desk.cpl
07/12/2023  09:08 PM           500,736 inetcpl.cpl
               3 File(s)      1,248,768 bytes
               0 Dir(s)  123,456,789,012 bytes free

data.en: If Windows can still boot, you can force it to restart into the Recovery Environment with the following command:

content.data:
C:\>shutdown /r /o
[A message appears that you're about to be signed out]

data.en: Scans and repairs corrupted or missing protected system files.

content.data:
X:\Sources>sfc /scannow

Beginning system scan. This process will take some time.
Beginning verification phase of system scan.
Verification 100% complete.
Windows Resource Protection did not find any integrity violations.

data.en: Repairs the underlying component store that sfc uses for repairs.

content.data:
X:\Sources>dism /online /cleanup-image /restorehealth

Deployment Image Servicing and Management tool
Image Version: 10.0.19042.867

[==========================100.0%==========================]
The restore operation completed successfully.

data.en: Repairs boot-related issues like a corrupt Master Boot Record (MBR) or Boot Configuration Data (BCD).

data: bootrec /fixmbr - Writes a new MBR.
bootrec /fixboot - Writes a new boot sector.
bootrec /rebuildbcd - Scans for Windows installations and adds them to the boot list.

content.data:
X:\Sources>bootrec /rebuildbcd

Scanning all disks for Windows installations.
Total identified Windows installations: 1
[1] C:\Windows
Add installation to boot list? Yes(Y)/No(N)/All(A): Y
The operation completed successfully.

data.en: Checks a disk for file system errors and bad sectors and attempts to repair them.

content.data:
X:\Sources>chkdsk c: /r
The type of the file system is NTFS.
Chkdsk cannot run because the volume is in use by another process.
Chkdsk may run if this volume is dismounted first.
ALL OPENED HANDLES TO THIS VOLUME WOULD THEN BE INVALID.
Would you like to force a dismount on this volume? (Y/N) Y
Volume dismounted. All opened handles to this volume are now invalid.
...
Windows has scanned the file system and found no problems.

data.en: Launches the System Restore graphical utility, allowing you to revert to a previous restore point.

content.data:
X:\Sources>rstrui.exe
[The System Restore graphical window opens]

data.en: Launches the Windows Memory Diagnostic tool to check your RAM for errors.

content.data:
X:\Sources>mdsched.exe
[The Windows Memory Diagnostic graphical window opens]

data.en: Adds, modifies, and removes user accounts from an elevated Command Prompt.

data: View all users: net user
Add a user: net user [username] [password] /add
Delete a user: net user [username] /delete
Change a password: net user [username] *

data.en: This command is used to add, display, modify, and delete user accounts. It must be run from an elevated Command Prompt.

content.data:
C:\WINDOWS\system32>net user

User accounts for \\DESKTOP-JIC01
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Administrator            DefaultAccount           Guest
JIC_Student              WDAGUtilityAccount
The command completed successfully.

! Add a user with a password
C:\WINDOWS\system32>net user Ahmed 12345 /add
The command completed successfully.

! Add a user, prompting for the password interactively (to hide it)
C:\WINDOWS\system32>net user Ali * /add
Type a password for the user: *****
Retype the password to confirm: *****
The command completed successfully.

data.en: Important Note: If the username contains spaces, it must be enclosed in quotation marks.

content.data:
C:\WINDOWS\system32>net user "Ahmed Admin" 123 /add
The command completed successfully.

C:\WINDOWS\system32>net user Ahmed
User name                    Ahmed
Full Name
Comment
User's comment
Country/region code          000 (System Default)
Account active               Yes
Account expires              Never
...
Local Group Memberships      *Users
Global Group memberships     *None
The command completed successfully.

! Deactivate the user account
C:\WINDOWS\system32>net user Ahmed /active:no
The command completed successfully.

! Activate the user account
C:\WINDOWS\system32>net user Ahmed /active:yes
The command completed successfully.

C:\WINDOWS\system32>net user Ahmed /delete
The command completed successfully.

data.en: This command is used to manage local groups on the computer.

content.data:
C:\WINDOWS\system32>net localgroup

Aliases for \\DESKTOP-JIC01
----------------------------------------------------------------
*Administrators
*Backup Operators
*Guests
*Power Users
*Users
The command completed successfully.

C:\WINDOWS\system32>net localgroup Sales /add
The command completed successfully.

data.en: Add a User to a Group

content.data:
! Add user "Ahmed" to the "Sales" group
C:\WINDOWS\system32>net localgroup Sales Ahmed /add
The command completed successfully.

! Add a user to the "Power Users" group (requires quotes)
C:\WINDOWS\system32>net localgroup "Power Users" Ahmed /add
The command completed successfully.

data.en: Displays the current computer name on the network.

content.data:
C:\>hostname
DESKTOP-JIC01

C:\>whoami
desktop-jic01\jic_student

! Display the user's Security Identifier (SID)
C:\>whoami /user
USER INFORMATION
----------------
User Name         SID
================= =============================================
desktop-jic01\jic_student S-1-5-21-123456789-987654321-1234567890-1001

data.en: Used to shut down or restart the computer.

content.data:
! Shut down immediately and force running applications to close
C:\>shutdown /s /f /t 0

data.en: For visual user and group management, you can use the "Local Users and Groups" tool.

content.data:
C:\>lusrmgr.msc
[A graphical window opens showing Users and Groups]

data.en: From inside this tool, you can right-click on a user to perform tasks like "Set Password", "Properties" (to change group membership), or disable the account.
VLANs (Virtual LANs) logically segment a switch into separate broadcast domains. Devices in one VLAN cannot communicate directly with devices in another VLAN without a router.
This example creates two VLANs (10 and 20) and assigns interfaces to them.

content.data:
! Create VLAN 10 and give it a name
Switch(config)#vlan 10
Switch(config-vlan)#name Students
Switch(config-vlan)#exit

! Create VLAN 20 and give it a name
Switch(config)#vlan 20
Switch(config-vlan)#name Faculty
Switch(config-vlan)#exit

! Assign interface FastEthernet0/1 to VLAN 10
Switch(config)#interface fastEthernet 0/1
Switch(config-if)#switchport mode access
Switch(config-if)#switchport access vlan 10
Switch(config-if)#exit

! Assign a range of interfaces to VLAN 20
Switch(config)#interface range fastEthernet 0/2 - 5
Switch(config-if-range)#switchport mode access
Switch(config-if-range)#switchport access vlan 20

Switch#show vlan brief

VLAN Name                             Status    Ports
---- -------------------------------- --------- -------------------------------
1    default                          active    Fa0/6, Fa0/7, Fa0/8, Fa0/9...
10   Students                         active    Fa0/1
20   Faculty                          active    Fa0/2, Fa0/3, Fa0/4, Fa0/5
...

data.en: A trunk port is a link that carries traffic for multiple VLANs between switches or between a switch and a router. The 802.1Q protocol is used to "tag" frames with VLAN information as they cross the trunk.

content.data:
! Configure the interface connecting to another switch as a trunk
Switch(config)#interface gigabitEthernet 0/1
Switch(config-if)#switchport mode trunk

Switch#show interfaces trunk

Port        Mode             Encapsulation  Status        Native vlan
Gig0/1      on               802.1q         trunking      1

Port        Vlans allowed on trunk
Gig0/1      1-4094
...

data.en: VTP allows you to manage VLANs on a single "server" switch, which then propagates the VLAN database to "client" switches in the same VTP domain. This saves time and ensures consistency.

data: Server: The default mode. You can create, modify, and delete VLANs. The server sends VTP advertisements to clients.
Client: Cannot create, modify, or delete VLANs. It listens to VTP advertisements from the server and synchronizes its VLAN database.
Transparent: Does not participate in VTP but will forward VTP advertisements. You can create/delete local VLANs, but they are not shared.

content.data:
! Configure the VTP Server Switch
VTP_Server(config)#vtp domain JIC
VTP_Server(config)#vtp mode server
VTP_Server(config)#vtp password cisco

! Configure the VTP Client Switch
VTP_Client(config)#vtp domain JIC
VTP_Client(config)#vtp mode client
VTP_Client(config)#vtp password cisco

SW1(config)# interface port-channel 1
SW2(config-if)# switchport mode trunk
Note: if you did all these steps and Vlans still not shows up , try to disconnect the links then reconnect them at same interface , and check VTP configuration on all switches

data.en: The Native VLAN is the one VLAN on an 802.1Q trunk that is sent **untagged**. For security, it is best practice to change the native VLAN from the default of VLAN 1 to an unused VLAN.

content.data:
Switch(config)#interface gigabitEthernet 0/1
Switch(config-if)#switchport trunk native vlan 999

data.en: A Voice VLAN allows an IP phone and a PC to share a single switch port. The switch places voice traffic in one VLAN and data traffic from the PC in another.

content.data:
! VLAN 100 for data (PC), VLAN 101 for voice (IP Phone)
Switch(config)#interface fastEthernet 0/10
Switch(config-if)#switchport mode access
Switch(config-if)#switchport access vlan 100
Switch(config-if)#switchport voice vlan 101

data.en: 5.Another Video reference for DTP, Native VLAN, and Voice VLAN configurations

Variable Length Subnet Masking (VLSM) is a technique that allows network administrators to divide an IP address space into subnets of different sizes. This is far more efficient than traditional "classful" subnetting, as it minimizes wasted IP addresses.
For example, you can use a /30 mask (2 host IPs) for a point-to-point link between routers and a /27 mask (30 host IPs) for a user LAN, all from the same original network block.
To use VLSM, you need to understand how to calculate the Network ID, Broadcast Address, and the range of usable host IPs for any given IP address and subnet mask.
Given the IP address 192.168.200.139 with a mask of 255.255.255.224 (/27):

data: Network Address: 192.168.200.128
Broadcast Address: 192.168.200.159
First Usable Host IP: 192.168.200.129
Last Usable Host IP: 192.168.200.158

data.en: Practical Example: Assigning IPs in Packet Tracer
Assigning an IP address to a PC in Packet Tracer is a fundamental skill for testing connectivity in any lab.

data: Click on the PC in the Packet Tracer workspace.
Go to the **Desktop** tab.
Click on **IP Configuration**.
Fill in the static IPv4 Address, Subnet Mask, and Default Gateway. The Default Gateway is the IP address of the router interface on the same network, which the PC will use to reach other networks.
